item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "Do you think I am an automaton? — a machine without feelings? and can bear to have my morsel of bread snatched from my lips, and my drop of living water dashed from my cup? Do you think, because I am poor, obscure, plain, and little, I am soulless and heartless? You think wrong! — I have as much soul as you — and full as much heart! And if God had gifted me with some beauty and much wealth, I should have made it as hard for you to leave me, as it is now for me to leave you. I am not talking to you now through the medium of custom, conventionalities, nor even of mortal flesh: it is my spirit that addresses your spirit; just as if both had passed through the grave, and we stood at God's feet, equal — as we are!" -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Voltaire
item.description: "Let us read, and let us dance; these two amusements will never do any harm to the world." -- Voltaire

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by David Foster Wallace
item.description: "The truth will set you free. But not until it is finished with you." -- David Foster Wallace

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by David Foster Wallace
item.description: "That sometimes human beings have to just sit in one place and, like, hurt. That you will become way less concerned with what other people think of you when you realize how seldom they do. That there is such a thing as raw, unalloyed, agendaless kindness. That it is possible to fall asleep during an anxiety attack. That concentrating on anything is very hard work." -- David Foster Wallace

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by David Foster Wallace
item.description: "You can be shaped, or you can be broken. There is not much in between. Try to learn. Be coachable. Try to learn from everybody, especially those who fail. This is hard. ... How promising you are as a Student of the Game is a function of what you can pay attention to without running away." -- David Foster Wallace

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Mary Doria Russell
item.description: "How can you hear your soul if everyone is talking?" -- Mary Doria Russell

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Marcus Tullius Cicero
item.description: "A room without books is like a body without a soul." -- Marcus Tullius Cicero

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Edward Abbey
item.description: "One final paragraph of advice: do not burn yourselves out. Be as I am - a reluctant enthusiast....a part-time crusader, a half-hearted fanatic. Save the other half of yourselves and your lives for pleasure and adventure. It is not enough to fight for the land; it is even more important to enjoy it. While you can. While it’s still here. So get out there and hunt and fish and mess around with your friends, ramble out yonder and explore the forests, climb the mountains, bag the peaks, run the rivers, breathe deep of that yet sweet and lucid air, sit quietly for a while and contemplate the precious stillness, the lovely, mysterious, and awesome space. Enjoy yourselves, keep your brain in your head and your head firmly attached to the body, the body active and alive, and I promise you this much; I promise you this one sweet victory over our enemies, over those desk-bound men and women with their hearts in a safe deposit box, and their eyes hypnotized by desk calculators. I promise you this; You will outlive the bastards." -- Edward Abbey

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Paul Theroux
item.description: "Fiction gives us a second chance that life denies us." -- Paul Theroux

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Paul Theroux
item.description: "Tourists don't know where they've been, travelers don't know where they're going." -- Paul Theroux

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Paul Theroux
item.description: "You go away for a long time and return a different person - you never come all the way back." -- Paul Theroux

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Mary Oliver
item.description: "I stood willingly and gladly in the characters of everything - other people, trees, clouds. And this is what I learned, that the world's otherness is antidote to confusion - that standing within this otherness - the beauty and the mystery of the world, out in the fields or deep inside books - can re-dignify the worst-stung heart." -- Mary Oliver

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Ernest Hemingway
item.description: "we would be together and have our books and at night be warm in bed together with the windows open and the stars bright." -- Ernest Hemingway

item.title: Stedwards add a quote by Anne Lamott
item.description: "You own everything that happened to you. Tell your stories. If people wanted you to write warmly about them, they should have behaved better." -- Anne Lamott
